docs.snippet: The year 2001 is not the first time in history that war and fear of disease and bioterror have gripped Americans at home. The country was born amid all three. Smallpox killed at least 130,000 North Americans during the Revolutionary War, writes th...
docs.lead_paragraph: The year 2001 is not the first time in history that war and fear of disease and bioterror have gripped Americans at home. The country was born amid all three. Smallpox killed at least 130,000 North Americans during the Revolutionary War, writes the historian Elizabeth Anne Fenn in her new book on the epidemic, ''Pox Americana.'' The jumpy American populace of that era stayed out of crowded places and sought to avoid trips to major cities. The mail was suspect -- Gen. George Washington decreed that letters from Boston had to be dipped in vinegar to kill any germs. Americans also worried about terrorism. In 1763, the British had deliberately infected Indians threatening the safety of Fort Pitt. There was evidence during the war, taken seriously by General Washington, that the British were deliberately spreading smallpox to American troops.
docs.abstract: Tina Rosenberg Editorial Observer column on fear of smallpox as weapon today and during Revolutionary War, when there was evidence that the British were deliberately spreading smallpox to American troops; says the poor suffered more back then and will likely suffer more if there is terrorist attack today (M)

headline.main: Editorial Observer; When Smallpox Struck During the Revolutionary War

docs.snippet: On a wintry Tuesday afternoon, Dr. Richard W. D'Souza, the vice president for oral health care of Pfizer, stood in front of a shelf stacked with gallon jugs labeled Artificial Saliva and Pooled Human Saliva, and spoke about the art of killing.    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: On a wintry Tuesday afternoon, Dr. Richard W. D'Souza, the vice president for oral health care of Pfizer, stood in front of a shelf stacked with gallon jugs labeled Artificial Saliva and Pooled Human Saliva, and spoke about the art of killing. ''They are nasty little buggers, and they should die,'' Dr. D'Souza said, offering a look through a microscope at a dish of proliferating microbes swabbed from a colleague's mouth. ''We have learned how to get rid of them, how to annihilate them, how to kill the wild germs in their natural habitat.''
docs.abstract: Article on turf war developing among major mint and gum manufacturers as they introduce new breath-freshening products and repackage old ones into hot new fashion accessories; photo (M)

headline.main: Breath Mints: A Hot War For America's Cool Mouths

docs.snippet: As architecture, the 50-foot concrete watchtower near Beach 216th Street and Palmer Drive is unremarkable. But as an image, the tower has what advertisers would call total market penetration. You see it on local T-shirts, restaurant menus, lightpo...
docs.lead_paragraph: As architecture, the 50-foot concrete watchtower near Beach 216th Street and Palmer Drive is unremarkable. But as an image, the tower has what advertisers would call total market penetration. You see it on local T-shirts, restaurant menus, lightpole banners and even Christmas tree ornaments. ''It's an unofficial emblem of the community,'' said Kevin Buckley, general manager of the Breezy Point Cooperative, which owns the 500-acre neighborhood.
docs.abstract: Concrete watchtower in Breezy Point, NY, disguised as lighthouse and deemed a hazard by US Corps of Engineers, is saved from demolition by Breezy Point Cooperative, which owns 500-acre neighborhood; tower has become war memorial and Corps of Engineers has agreed to shore up structure; photo (M)

headline.main: A Neighborhood Takes to Heart A Watchtower Built for War

docs.snippet: Under pressure from the United States to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes court or face an aid freeze, Serbia's prime minister said today that a suspect might be sent to The Hague within days.    Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic spoke at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the United States to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes court or face an aid freeze, Serbia's prime minister said today that a suspect might be sent to The Hague within days. Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic spoke at a news conference to show that Serbia, part of the Yugoslav federation with Montenegro, is cooperating with the court before a deadline set by the United States passes on Sunday.
docs.abstract: Serb Prime Min Zoran Djindjic says Serbia is cooperating with war crimes tribunal and may send suspect to The Hague within days; about $40 million in US aid will be suspected if Bush administration does not certify compliance with court (S)

headline.main: Leader Says Serbia Will Cooperate With War Court

docs.snippet: The Tokyo High Court rejected an appeal for government compensation for 150,000 civilians and military personnel held prisoner in Asia during World War II. The ruling was the latest in a string of legal setbacks for people seeking compensation fro...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Tokyo High Court rejected an appeal for government compensation for 150,000 civilians and military personnel held prisoner in Asia during World War II. The ruling was the latest in a string of legal setbacks for people seeking compensation from Japan for war-related atrocities and human rights abuses. The seven plaintiffs who represent larger organizations of former prisoners, said they would make a final appeal in the seven-year-old case. Howard W. French (NYT)
docs.abstract: Tokyo High Court rejects appeal for government compensation for 150,000 civilians and military personnel held prisoner in Asia during World War II; ruling is latest in string of setbacks for people seeking compensation from Japan for war-related atrocities (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: War Prisoners Lose Compensation Bid

docs.snippet: Frustrated by their inability to identify a vast majority of captured fighters of Al Qaeda and the Taliban, federal authorities are proposing to create a DNA databank of terrorism suspects by analyzing blood samples from thousands of detainees bei...
docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by their inability to identify a vast majority of captured fighters of Al Qaeda and the Taliban, federal authorities are proposing to create a DNA databank of terrorism suspects by analyzing blood samples from thousands of detainees being held in Afghanistan and Cuba, government officials said. The officials said the DNA database could help in tracking terrorism suspects in the future. They said that would be particularly important because they now believed that many of the detainees would have to be released before the government was certain who they are.
docs.abstract: Federal authorities want to create DNA databank of terrorism suspects by analyzing blood samples from thousands of captured fighters of Al Qaeda and Taliban being held in Afghanistan and at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba; FBI authorities say they are frustrated by their inability to identify vast majority of detainees, and worried that many of them will be released before government is certain who they are; say information from proposed DNA database could also play role in some current investigations, including case of Richard Reid, accused of trying to blow up trans-Atlantic flight with explosives hidden in his shoes; say DNA might help them trace source of hairs found in Reid's shoes and possibly identify accomplice; DNA database proposal is being reviewed by Justice Dept; Congressional approval would be required; civil liberties groups are likely to fight such attempts to expand use of DNA profiling (M)

headline.main: U.S. Seeks DNA Of All Captives In Afghan War

byline.original: By DAVID JOHNSTON and JAMES RISEN

docs.snippet: As dusk fell, a local storekeeper walked to the spot where he had witnessed the shooting of Sgt. First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, the only American serviceman to die from hostile fire in the war in Afghanistan.    The storekeeper, Izatullah Abdul ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As dusk fell, a local storekeeper walked to the spot where he had witnessed the shooting of Sgt. First Class Nathan Ross Chapman, the only American serviceman to die from hostile fire in the war in Afghanistan. The storekeeper, Izatullah Abdul Mutmain, chanted a requiem he composed spontaneously for Sergeant Chapman, 31, a Special Forces soldier who died on Jan. 4 after being struck by rifle fire while riding in a pickup truck. ''I have seen Al Qaeda killing an American,'' the merchant sang in a quavering falsetto, ''and it wounds my heart and soul.''
docs.abstract: Local leaders and some witnesses say Sgt Nathan Ross Chapman, American Special Forces soldier killed in Khost, Afghanistan, Jan 4, fell victim to rivalry between Afghan warlords, not to local fighters secretly loyal to Al Qaeda and Taliban as reported by Pentagon; forces of warlord Zakim Khan Zadran hold rival, Padsha Khan Zadran, ordered his men to fire on Americans while they were escorted by Zakin Khan Zadran's security guards to convince Americans to switch to their side; map; diagram; photos (M)

headline.main: U.S. War Victim Rode Into Afghan Turf Fight
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: A SOLDIER'S STORY

docs.snippet: In the complex and secretive world in which politicians and bureaucrats maneuver for power in France, Henri Loyrette, the new director of the Louvre, is discovering the perils of candor. Ten days ago, seemingly unaware that he was entering a dange...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the complex and secretive world in which politicians and bureaucrats maneuver for power in France, Henri Loyrette, the new director of the Louvre, is discovering the perils of candor. Ten days ago, seemingly unaware that he was entering a danger zone, he echoed his predecessor's lament that budget restrictions required the museum to close one-quarter of its galleries every day because of a shortage of security guards. By noting what is difficult to ignore, he has now earned himself a highly unusual public rebuke from the culture minister, Catherine Tasca, who has accused him of lack of discipline, grandstanding and even of flirting with the idea of privatizing the museum. Ms. Tasca also used the occasion to criticize Mr. Loyrette's predecessor, Pierre Rosenberg, for waging what she described as a Rabelaisian war against the country's cultural authorities.
docs.abstract: Many of France's cultural leaders are stunned when Culture Min Catherine Tasca publicly reprimands Louvre director Henri Loyrette and his predecessor, Pierre Rosenberg, for complaining about budget constraints that force gallery closings because of shortage of security guards; attack on two respected museum figures deepens rift between politicians and those directly running government-owned institutions; photos (M)

headline.main: French Government and the Louvre in a War of Words

docs.snippet: It may be the ultimate act for the nation's legions of Civil War re-enactors, those buffs in uniform who worshipfully trek the old battlegrounds from Fort Sumter to Appomattox: They can now buy a burial plot in a new cemetery being carved from the...
docs.lead_paragraph: It may be the ultimate act for the nation's legions of Civil War re-enactors, those buffs in uniform who worshipfully trek the old battlegrounds from Fort Sumter to Appomattox: They can now buy a burial plot in a new cemetery being carved from the hallowed earth of the Battle of Chancellorsville. ''Choose a final resting place that will connect with your life's passion for the War Between the States,'' declares a sales brochure for the cemetery, which offers Johnny Reb or Yankee Bluecoat plaques and optional North-South burial sections for those who prefer to leave the issue that way for ever and ever.
docs.abstract: Chancellorsville Memorial Garden, Civil War theme park cemetery, is planned for fields crisscrossed by troops during Battle of Chancellorsville near Fredricksburg, Va; is being designed as final resting place for civil war buffs; will offer optional North-South burial sections; 373-acre cemetery is brainchild of Joe Barreiro, transplanted New Yorker; photos; maps (M)

headline.main: Burial Theme Park Invites Civil War Buffs to R.I.P.

docs.snippet: First there is the smoke from the bomb, lifting off the mountains, roaming into the blue sky. Then comes the noise, an abrupt boom. Finally the rumble arrives, pulsing through the ground from three miles away.    This village is a fine and dreadfu...
docs.lead_paragraph: First there is the smoke from the bomb, lifting off the mountains, roaming into the blue sky. Then comes the noise, an abrupt boom. Finally the rumble arrives, pulsing through the ground from three miles away. This village is a fine and dreadful place to watch the American air attack. Sher Baz Khan, an old man with a wrinkled face, a white beard and a regretful pair of eyes, was watching intently today. It was his home being destroyed.
docs.abstract: Shah-i-Kot, collection of mountain villages in eastern Afghanistan that is scene of fierce fighting between US-led forces and those of Al Qaeda and Taliban, is dealt double blow; residents were forced to leave by Taliban who favored it as place to make last stand; was home to mujahedeen base in 1980's during war against Russians, and is considered hallowed ground; is currently being destroyed by bombs dropped by US warplanes; photo (M)

headline.main: Taliban and War Deliver a Double Blow to Villagers
